reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central dependency of the essay: that post-AGI “reasonably good conditions” plus enough pluralism/representation will obtain such that partial AM-convergence and bargaining can matter. If race dynamics reliably concentrate power in early winners selected for speed/defection/lock-in, that would substantially lower the plausibility of the essay’s more optimistic bargaining-based route to mostly-great futures (and links directly to the essay’s own ‘concentration of power’ blocker). However, the essay already flags concentration-of-power and early lock-in as key blockers and explicitly conditions many claims on ‘reasonably good conditions’, so the critique partly presses something the essay is already aware of rather than cleanly refuting a main conditional claim. The argument is plausible but underspecified (no concrete model/evidence for the selection effect or for governance/reflective postures being systematically dominated), making it a partial rather than decisive refutation. Most statements are directionally credible, though some empirical/strategic claims are speculative, so correctness is good but not near-1.
title: Race dynamics select for defectors who undermine the paper's bargaining prerequisites
